title: Happy Number
description: Write an algorithm to determine if a number n is happy. A happy number is a number defined by the following process: Starting with any positive integer, replace the number by the sum of the squares of its digits. Repeat the process until the number equals 1 (where it will stay), or it loops endlessly in a cycle which does not include 1. Those numbers for which this process ends in 1 are happy. Return true if n is a happy number, and false if not.

brute-force.name: HashSet
brute-force.description: Detect cycle using a hash set.

steps.instruction: Define the function is_happy that takes n.

steps.hint: Initialize a set to keep track of visited numbers.

steps.instruction: Loop while n not in visit.
steps.placeholderCode:
while n not in visit:
        visit.add(n)
        n = sum([int(x) ** 2 for x in str(n)])
        if n == 1: return True
steps.hint: Loop until `n` is in `visit`. Add `n` to `visit`, calculate the sum of squares of digits, and update `n`. If `n` becomes 1, return True.
steps.solutionCode:
while n not in visit:
        visit.add(n)
        n = sum([int(x) ** 2 for x in str(n)])
        if n == 1: return True
